Tips.title: General Assessment
Tips.description: Use 'overall' to summarize a situation after considering all individual parts.
Tips.example: She received positive feedback, but overall, there is room for improvement.

Tips.title: Avoid Replacement
Tips.description: 'Overall' cannot be interchanged with 'every' or 'each'; it's about the collective picture, not the individual elements.
Tips.example: Overall, the team did well, though each member faced some challenges.

Tips.title: Time Reflection
Tips.description: Use 'overall' when reflecting on a period of time or experience as a whole.
Tips.example: The weather was unpredictable, but overall, we had a sunny week.

senses.de: Including all the things or people that are involved in a particular situation
senses.ex: The overall cost of the trip was $200

Tips.title: Comprehensive Sum
Tips.description: The adjective 'overall' implies that everything has been counted or considered in a total.
Tips.example: The overall feedback from the surveys was incredibly positive.

Tips.title: Comparisons Clarified
Tips.description: Use 'overall' to contrast a summary with specific examples or details.
Tips.example: There were minor issues, but the overall result was satisfactory.

senses.de: A loose, one-piece garment combining trousers and a top, usually made of a sturdy fabric

Tips.title: Not Just Fashion
Tips.description: Although 'overalls' are commonly associated with clothing, they represent a type or category rather than a specific fashion trend.
Tips.example: The farmer pulled on his overalls before heading out to the field.

Tips.title: Practical Attire
Tips.description: Overalls are often worn for their functionality and protection in labor-intensive work.
Tips.example: The artist wore overalls to keep her clothes clean while painting.

Complete.wordDefinition:
Complete means something is finished or done entirely without any missing parts. For example, if you complete your homework, that means you finished all the assigned tasks.

Complete is often used when referring to a specific task or project.

Complete refers to the finished state of something while overall refers to the entirety of something.

Comprehensive.wordDefinition:
Comprehensive refers to something that is complete and covers all aspects or details of a particular subject. For example, a comprehensive health check-up would include all necessary tests and examinations to assess a person's overall health.

Both words can be applicable in different situations, but comprehensive is more specific and detailed while overall is more general and broad.

Entirety.wordDefinition:
Entirety means the whole or complete thing, without any part missing. It's usually used to refer to something that is made up of many individual parts or components.

For example: "He ate the entirety of the pizza by himself."

The main difference between these two words is that entirety refers to completeness and overall refers to taking everything into consideration.

Both words can be used in similar contexts, but entirety is more specific and overall is more general.

General.wordDefinition:
General refers to things that are basic or common, while overall refers to things that are comprehensive or include everything.

For example, a general description of a city might include information about its population and location, while an overall description might include information about its culture, economy, and geography.

General is more appropriate when you want to talk about something that is simple or straightforward, while the word overall is more appropriate when you want to talk about something that is complex or complete.

Holistic.wordDefinition:
Holistic refers to an approach that considers the whole system or person, taking into account all aspects and how they work together.

For example, a holistic approach to health might consider a person's diet, exercise routine, emotional state, and social support system.

Holistic is more specific and takes a deeper dive, while overall is more general and covers a broader range.

Inclusive.wordDefinition:
Inclusive means something that includes everything and caters to everyone. This is applicable when you want to talk about a group or idea that includes all types of people without any discrimination.

For example, "Our school promotes inclusive education and welcomes students from all backgrounds."

To summarize, inclusive refers to something that caters to everyone and overall refers to something that covers everything in a general sense.

Total.wordDefinition:
Total refers to the complete or entire amount of something. For example, "The total cost of the project was $100,000.".

Overall is used when talking about the overall performance, outcome, or impression of something. Total is used when referring to the total amount or quantity of something.

To summarize, overall refers to a general view or summary, while total refers to the complete amount.

Whole.wordDefinition:
Whole refers to the complete amount or extent of something, without any parts or elements missing.

It is often used when describing a singular object, such as "I ate the whole pizza."

In simpler terms, overall is used when talking about the entirety of something and whole is used when talking about something complete without any missing parts or elements.

quotes.Text: I think, as an artist, the overall goal is to teach and educate no matter what the song is about. Somewhere where a listener can get something out of it, something that can give them help to move forward, help them learn something, analyze something in a different way, or think about something.

quotes.Text: The programs I do with my trainer are amazing for overall strength and have a major focus on building my core. We do a lot of unique exercises that shake up the nervous system, which builds my balance and propreception. That's really important for my sport.
